author: Tom McGhee
title: Back-up guitar players put the boom in Denver Stock Show fiddle contest
text:
January 6, 2017 Fan favorite Denver Broncos mascot Thunder will take his turn as Stock Show parade grand marshal — in 2018 
Division levels start with Small Fry, children 8-years-old and younger, and there is no upper age limit. 
“Some of these little kids play unbelievably great,” McKenzie said. “It actually shocks people when this cute kid walks on stage in their cowboy suit and just cuts everybody in half.” 
But even older fiddlers can be inexperienced, and though the guitar player is there to help them stay on the beat, sometimes a fiddler can get tangled in the song’s timing. 
That doesn’t happen often, said Mature, 50. “There’s been times, but for the most part we try to rehearse the round before we go on stage, and 95 percent of the time we get through it. Your function is to provide a good solid rhythm for the fiddler,” even if they sometimes stumble, he said. 
While he knows most of the breakdowns and tunes of choice that are performed, some fiddlers perform a waltz they have written themselves. “Some of those can be tricky,” Mature said. 
Mature and McKenzie play with anyone who wants their help, and generally sit in with about three-quarters of the contestants. 
They often do a practice run with the fiddlers they will back up at a warm-up area near the stage at the Beef Palace Auction Arena, on the stock show grounds, where the contest is held. 
Some competitors bring their own guitar player, sometimes a family member. Sisters Mackenzie and Elyssa Johnston are both competing in the contest, and McKenzie, 16, will also play back-up guitar for Elyssa, 11, when the younger girl performs. 
Both Mature and McKenzie have been playing stringed instruments for most of their lives. “I grew up around fiddle players,” Mature said. “My brother plays fiddle, and my dad plays guitar. I have several cousins who play, so every time there was a family function I would bring a guitar.” 
He began playing as an accompanist at fiddle contests when he was 16, and since then has backed up fiddlers at competitions throughout the country, including the National Oldtime Fiddlers’ Contest and Festival in Weiser, Idaho. “You show up, and someone asks you to get your guitar out, and it kind of rolls from there.” 
Mature, who worked as an accountant for the state of Texas, retired from that job recently, and traveled to France to back up Texas Oldtime fiddle champion Wes Westmoreland, whose musical accomplishments include a 10-year stint playing fiddle in country songwriter and singer Mel Tillis’ band. 
Oregon native McKenzie has lived in Texas for 30 years. He has shared the stage with country stars Marty Stuart, Ricky Skaggs and Merle Haggard, and has backed up numerous fiddlers, including award-winning bluegrass player Michael Cleveland. 
He now plays guitar, and sings, with the Western Fliers , a Texas-based trio that features champion fiddler and Boulder resident Katie Glassman and bass player Gavin Kelso. 
McKenzie began playing guitar when he was a boy, but moved to fiddle after becoming friends with and playing back-up guitar for Texas fiddle legend Benny Thomasson. 
He is a three-time world champion fiddler who has won more than 100 fiddle contests. 
A problem with his left hand and thumb made it difficult for him to play fiddle, and he switched to guitar in the late ’90s. However, “when a jam session breaks out, there is a high possibility that I am going to bust out the fiddle.” Tags: Tom McGhee A general assignment reporter for The Denver Post, Tom McGhee has covered business, police, courts, higher education and breaking news. He came to The Post from Albuquerque, N.M., where he worked for a year and a half covering utilities. He began his journalism career in New York City, worked for a pair of community weeklies that covered the west side of Manhattan from 14th Street to 125th Street.
